|blank1_info = 0617867 |footnotes = }} 'Worcester' ( ) is a city and
the county seat of Worcester County, Massachusetts, United States. Named after
Worcester, England, as of the 2010 Census the city's population was 181,045, making it the second largest city in New England
after Boston. The third largest city is Providence, Rhode Island, with a
population of 178,042.  Worcester is located approximately west of Boston,
and east of Springfield. Due to its location in central Massachusetts, amidst
Massachusetts' major metropolitan regions, Worcester is known as the "Heart of
the Commonwealth", thus, a heart is the official symbol of the city.

Worcester was considered its own region for centuries; however, with the
encroachment of Boston's suburbs, it now marks the western periphery of the Boston-Worcester-
Manchester (MA-RI-NH) U.S. Census Combined Statistical Area (CSA) (Greater
Boston). The city features many examples of Victorian-era mill architecture.
categories: Populated places in Worcester County, Massachusetts
